scenes.goal: Introduce recursion as a problem-solving technique where a function calls itself.
visual_elements: Simple flowchart showing a function calling itself
Text: 'Solving a problem by breaking it into smaller, similar problems'
scenes.narrative_intent: Set the stage and define recursion in simple terms.

scenes.goal: Explain the critical concept of the base case to stop recursion.
visual_elements: Diagram of a recursive function with a highlighted 'Base Case' condition
Animation: A countdown from 5 to 0, stopping at 0
Text: 'Without a base case: Infinite recursion (Stack Overflow)'
scenes.narrative_intent: Emphasize the necessity of a stopping condition.

scenes.goal: Demonstrate recursion using the classic factorial example (n!).
visual_elements: Visual tree: Factorial(4) branching to Factorial(3), etc.
scenes.narrative_intent: Walk through a concrete mathematical example.

scenes.goal: Visualize how the call stack manages memory during recursion.
visual_elements: Animation: Stack unwinding as values return
scenes.narrative_intent: Explain the memory overhead and execution flow.

visual_elements: Side-by-side code snippets: Recursive vs Iterative Factorial
Comparison table: Pros (readability) vs Cons (stack depth)
Graphic: 'Many problems are naturally recursive (Trees, DFS)'
scenes.narrative_intent: Contextualize when to use recursion over loops.

visual_elements: Checklist: Base Case, Recursive Step, Call Stack
